I was so amazed at your letter to Leon, O most learned Bucere, that I could not but offer these few words of mine in response. I am sure you will use them for the good, since they are sent in a friendly spirit. Your letter chiefly seeks to persuade us to subscribe to Luther's beliefs or give in to his views on the Eucharist; and thus your Saxon followers have subscribed to his doctrines. Before you begin, you try to gain a right to rely on your own faith, since you allow Leon to be rich in his own. To this I would not have much objection, provided that faith keeps to its own rule. We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing by the word of God" [Rom 10:17]. We also know that the apostle said: "If any man speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God" [1 Pet 4:11]; "If anything is revealed to another who is seated, let the first keep silent" [1 Cor 14:30]; "But the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets" [1 Cor 14:32f], and elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, be thus minded; and if in anything ye are otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you" [Phil 3:15].

seg.output: When I read your letter to Leo, Bucere, the most learned, I was so amazed that I couldn't help but respond to your communication.I do not doubt that you are acting in good faith and that this letter is motivated by friendship.Your letter mainly aims to persuade us to subscribe to or yield to Luther's view on the Eucharist, as the Saxons have done in their creed.Before you start, you try to secure the right to follow your own faith, while allowing Leo to do the same.I wouldn't have objected to this too much, as long as the faith stays within its own boundaries.We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God" [Romans 10:17], and the apostle said: "If anyone speaks, let them speak as the oracles of God" [1 Peter 4:11]; "if something is revealed to another who is seated, the first should keep silent" [1 Corinthians 14:30]; "the prophets are subject to the spirits, for God is not the author of confusion but of peace" [1 Corinthians 14:32-33], and elsewhere: "Let us, then, who are perfect, think this way; and if someone thinks differently, God will reveal this to them, yet so that we may all come to the same conclusion and remain within the same boundaries" [Philippians 3:15-16].Therefore, we accept faith that comes from the word of truth, whether it is yours, Bucere, or someone else's; and if not, we reject it with modesty.The same applies to Luther's case.

seg.output: I was amazed at your letter to Leon, most learned Bucer, so much so that I could not help but respond with our own thoughts. I have no doubt that you will be wise in considering these, as they were sent in friendship. The main point of your letter is to persuade us to subscribe to or yield to Luther in the Eucharist matter, as you have done in Saxony. Before you begin, you must try to secure that you can enjoy your own faith, since you permit Leon to be plenty. To this I would not have much objection provided faith keeps to its own rule. We know that "faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the Word of God" [Romans 10:17], and we know that the Apostle wrote: "If anyone speaks, let them speak as the oracles of God" [1 Peter 4:11]; "but if a revelation is made to another who is seated, let the first keep silent" [1 Corinthians 14:30]; "but the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion but of peace" [1 Corinthians 14:32-33], and elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this. And if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you. Nevertheless, to us it is the same God who works all things in all" [Philippians 3:15-16]. And so, if we receive faith, either yours, my Bucer, or that of another, from the Word of Truth, we accept it, but if not, we reject it modestly. The same is true of Luther's matter. If he has prophetic Spirit, he is subject to the prophets, and if he is subject to the prophets, he will certainly confess the truth, and if he confesses the truth, all discord will be removed. But if he does not submit, but stirs up trouble, he does not have the Spirit of God, who is the author of peace, not trouble.

seg.output: I was so amazed at your letter to Leon, learned Buzer, that I could not help but respond with our own humble thoughts. I have no doubt that you will treat them with the same good intentions with which they were sent. Your letter is mainly focused on convincing us to subscribe to or yield to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, as the Saxons have done with their dogma. Before beginning, strive to obtain the right to enjoy your own faith, since you allow Leon to abound in his own. To which I would not have much objection, provided his faith keeps its own rule. We know that "faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God" [Rom 10:17]. We also know that the Apostle has written: "If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God" [1 Pet 4:11]; "If there is anything revealed to another who sits by, let the first keep silent" [1 Cor 14:30]; "But the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion but of peace" [1 Cor 14:32f], and elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this: and if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you. Nevertheless, whereto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule" [Phil 3:15f]. Therefore, if the faith, be it yours, Buzer, or that of any other, is from the word of truth, we accept it; if not, we reject it with modesty. The same applies to Luther's matter. If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he must be subject to the prophets; and if so, he will confess the truth, and thus all discord will be removed. But if he does not submit himself, but instead stirs up a mob, he does not have the Spirit of God, who is the author of peace, and not of tumult. Who therefore should subscribe to him? Paul does not want us to accept the weaker for the sake of harmony, but he says that the weaker are led by God in such a way that they embrace what is more perfect.

seg.output: I was so amazed by your letter to Leon, most learned Bucer, that I could not help but offer these our humble thoughts in response.I have no doubt that you will use them for the benefit of a friend.Your main aim in the letter is to persuade us to subscribe to or give in to Luther's doctrine on the Eucharist, as the Saxons have done.But before you begin, you should attempt to secure the right to rely on your own faith, since you allow Leon to rely on his own.I would not be strongly opposed to this, provided it keeps within the bounds of faith.For we know that “faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God” [Rom 10:17], and that it is written by the Apostle: “If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God” [1 Pet 4:11]; “if a revelation is made to another sitting by, let the first keep silent” [1 Cor 14:30]; “the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.For God is not a God of confusion but of peace” [1 Cor 14:32f], and elsewhere: “Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this way.And if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you”, namely, that which the perfect think, “yet so as by the majority it is kept in the same form” [Phil 3:15f].And so, if the faith of you, my Bucer, or of anyone else, is from the word of truth, we receive it; otherwise, we decline it with modesty.And so in the affair of Luther.If Luther has a prophetic spirit, it is subject to the prophets; furthermore, if it is subject to the prophets, it will certainly confess the truth, and if it confesses the truth, all discord will be removed.But if it is not subject but stirs up the people, it does not have the spirit of God who is the author of peace, not of confusion.Therefore, who should subscribe to him?Paul does not want us to receive anything weakly for the sake of peace, but says that the weak should be led by God to embrace that which is perfect.Now, you yourself, most learned Bucer, may explain what is more perfect in the Eucharist.Explain to us, then, most learned Bucer, what is that doctrine that we, by God, have obtained in the Eucharist, in which we agree and proceed by the same rule, Luther's or our own.

seg.output: I was so amazed at your letter to Leon, learned Bucer, that I could not help but respond with these meager words of ours.I have no doubt that you would consult for the good, since these words have been written in friendship.The main point of your letter is to persuade us to either subscribe to Luther's views or yield in the matter of the Eucharist; so you say that the Saxons have subscribed to the dogma.Before you start, you try to secure that you can enjoy your faith, since you allow Leon to abound in his.To which I would not have much objection, as long as his faith follows its rule.For we know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God" [Rom 10:17].We also know that the apostle has written: "If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God" [1 Pet 4:11]; "if there is anything revealed to another who sits by, let the first keep silent" [1 Cor 14:30]; "the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace" [1 Cor 14:32f], and elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, be thus minded.And if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you.Nevertheless, let us follow the same rule" [Phil 3:15f].And therefore, if the faith is of the word of truth, either yours, my Bucer, or that of any other, we accept it, but if otherwise, we decline with modesty.The same goes for the matter of Luther.If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he is subject to the prophets, and if he is subject to the prophets, he will confess the truth, and if he confesses this, all disagreement will be removed.But if he is not subject, but stirs up the crowds, he does not have the spirit of God, who is the author of peace, not of confusion.So who will subscribe to him?Paul indeed does not want to accept the weaker for the sake of agreement, but says that the weaker are to be led by God to accept what is more perfect.And now you yourself, Bucer, will be able to explain what is more perfect in the Eucharist.Explain to us then, learned Bucer, what kind of doctrine it is that we have attained from God in the Eucharist, in which we agree and proceed by the same rule, Luther's or ours.Surely Luther's dogma is weaker, which your own books prove, and so ours is more perfect.For if the opinion of both is the same, why do you labor for agreement, which is otherwise attained by consent of truth?

seg.output: You say: "I know from words and writings that nothing is given by words or sacraments except for admonishment and exercise of the mind to faith". And if it were so, that Luther himself would freely confess what you are unwilling to impose on him. You would certainly wish that Luther would speak, think and understand his own words in this way. And perhaps he would do it, if you appealed to him in a calm manner rather than contentious one. But he doesn't want to be like that. For if he ever wanted to, you would not have spent so much labor in vain trying to repair the concord, which you yourself admit, that you have been frustrated time and again by written dialogues and conversations held in Marburg, Augsburg and Coburg. What then do we do with one who is thinking, other than what he himself thinks or wants to think? What are we forcing upon him, I ask, who has already surrendered himself to the devil, if he begins to think as you preach of him? What about you, yourself in this very letter, when you say: "If he believes and teaches of the promise of God a certain bodily presence of Christ above that which inserts itself into our minds, yet does not clearly acknowledge that this presence and faith are for anyone's salvation, but places everything in that faith in which it is believed that Christ died for us, how great, I ask, is this error?". Do you think this error should be pardoned in him? And indeed we would pardon it, if we ever found in this man anything of sincere candor, if he did not take advantage of our indulgence, and if it were possible to pardon it through the simplicity of truth. What need is there to invent another presence than that which is delivered in the scriptures? What promises of God will he cite for a bodily presence?

seg.output: You say: "I know from words and writings, that nothing gives more than an admonition and exercise of the mind to faith through words or sacraments". And how I wish it were so, and that Luther himself would freely confess what you unwilling impose on him. You would indeed earnestly wish Luther to speak, think and understand his own words in this manner. And perhaps he would, if you were to appeal to him in a tranquil rather than a contentious manner. But he does not wish to be such. For if ever he had wanted to, you would not have spent so much effort in vain in trying to restore unity, as you yourself admit, frustrated time and again by written dialogues and conversations held in Marburg, Augsburg and Coburg. So what other choice do we have than to make him think or want to think what he himself thinks? What are we, I ask, forcing on him, who has already given himself to the devil, if he were to come to think, as you proclaim, in this manner? What of the fact that in this very letter of yours you say: "If he believes and teaches, on the promise of God, a certain corporal presence of Christ over the Eucharist, which inserts itself into our minds, yet declares that neither this presence nor this faith is of any benefit for salvation, but instead places all of this in a faith by which Christ is believed to have died for us - what great error is this, I pray, that you deem fit to forgive him? And surely we would forgive him, if ever we had found anything of candid sincerity in him, if he were not to abuse our indulgence, nay, if it were permissible to forgive him through the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to invent another presence than the one which has been handed down by scripture? Which promises of God will he cite for us concerning a corporal presence? But what need was there to invent a corporal presence, indeed another faith with the sophists, which would not be beneficial? But if he admits that all these figments of his, which are currently being debated, are of no benefit for salvation, then he certainly argues for nothing, but has condemned us with a treacherous and wicked judgment, nay, he has until now lured the Church of God.

seg.output: You say: "I know from words and writings that nothing gives except admonition and exercise of the mind to faith, either by words or sacraments". And may it be so, and Luther himself confesses freely what you are imposing on the unwilling. You would indeed earnestly wish Luther to speak, think, and understand his own words thus. And perhaps he would do so, if you called him from contentious to tranquil. But he does not wish to be so. For if he ever had so wished, you would not have spent so much labor in vain on reconciling, as you yourself confess, that you were often frustrated by written dialogue and conversations held at Marburg, Augsburg, and Coburg. What then do we do with one who thinks, but does not want to think, or what do we impose on Satan himself, if he begins to think, as you preach about him? What do you yourself say in this very letter of yours: "If he believes and teaches about the Eucharist, from the promise of God, a certain corporeal presence of Christ above it, by which it inserts itself into our minds, although he confesses that neither this presence nor this faith is of any use for salvation, but places all in that faith, in which Christ is believed to have died for us, what great error, I pray, do you consider this to be forgiven? And we would certainly forgive it, if ever we had found anything of candid sincerity in this man, if he did not abuse our indulgence, yea, if it were lawful to forgive it through the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to feign another presence than that which is delivered by the Scriptures? What promises of God will he cite concerning a corporeal presence? But what need was there to posit a corporeal presence, indeed to devise another faith with the sophists, than that which is salutary? But if he confesses that all these his figments, about which we now dispute, do nothing for salvation, he certainly contends for nothing, but has condemned us by a most wicked and impious judgment, yea, he has hitherto mocked the Church of God. For if flesh eaten is of no benefit, why does he perpetually draw the thread of contention? Why does he pursue those that teach it, drive them into exile, and advise them to be slain? Or is this the sincerity of a theologian, to cover the light of truth with darkness, to hide impostures in open matters, and to tie snares in the simplicity of Christianity, and all this with the spirit of contention and arrogance?

Nam quod aliud fecimus, quam quod cum simplicitate et veritate evangelii nostri dei non sine virtute et sapientia dei?»
You say: "I know from words and writings that nothing is given by words or sacraments except admonition and exercise to faith." And how good it would be if it were so and even Luther himself would freely confess what you are forcing on the unwilling. You would indeed wish Luther to talk, think and understand his own words in this way. And perhaps he would do it, if you were to call him away from the contentious to the tranquil. But he does not want to be so. For if he ever wanted to, you would not have wasted so much labour in vain in bringing about concord, which you yourself confess, being often frustrated in the dialogue written, and in the conversations at Marburg, Augsburg and Coburg. What then do we do with him who thinks, but does not want to think or will to think? What do we force on him by Satan, if he begins to think as you preach of him? What of it that you yourself in this same letter say: "If he believes and teaches concerning the Eucharist from the promise of God a certain corporal presence of Christ over it, by which it enters into our minds, yet he openly confesses that neither this presence nor this faith is of any service to salvation, but places all in that faith wherein Christ is believed to have died for us: what great error, I pray you, do you think this is to be forgiven?" And truly we would forgive it, if ever we found anything of candid sincerity in this man, if he did not abuse our indulgence, nay, if it were lawful to forgive it by the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to feign any other presence than that which is delivered in the Scriptures? What promise of God will he cite concerning a corporal presence? But what need was there to devise a corporal presence, and in fine a faith with the sophists different from that which is salutary? But if he confesses that all his figments, which are in the mean time discoursed of, do nothing for salvation, he certainly contends for a thing of nought, but hath condemned us with a very wicked and impious judgment, yea, hath hitherto mocked the Church of God. For if the eating of flesh profiteth nothing, why doth he still draw the string of contention? Why doth he persecute them that teach it, thrust them into banishment, and persuade to slay them? Or is this the sincerity of a divine, to enwrap the light of truth in darkness, cover impostures in a thing manifest, and to tie knots in the simplicity of the Christian faith, and to do all this out of a zeal of contention and arrogance? Or is it not come into our minds, what the poet said: "The truth is plain in itself, the crooked speech of him that soweth lies needeth the advice of wise men," or that most sacred saying of Paul: "Do I think according to the flesh, that there should be with me yes and no? But I call God to witness, that our word toward you was not yea and nay. For the things which were done, were done in simplicity and truth of the Gospel of God, and not with guile and wisdom of men"?

seg.output: You say: "I know from words and writings that nothing is attributed either by words or by sacraments except for the admonition and exercise of the mind to faith". And if only it were so, and Luther himself would freely confess what you are forcing upon the unwilling. You would very much like Luther to talk, think and understand his own words in this way. And perhaps he would, if you appealed to him calmly instead of contentiously. But he does not want to be like that. For if he ever wanted to, you would not have spent so much effort in vain trying to reconcile, as you yourself admit, being often frustrated in the written dialogue, and in the conversations held in Marburg, in Augsburg and in Coburg. So what else can we do with one who thinks, but to make him think what he thinks or wants to think? What, I ask, are we forcing on him of Satan, if he begins to think, as you preach about him? What is that in your own letter when you say: "If he believes and teaches about the Eucharist, from the promise of God, a certain bodily presence of Christ above it, although he does not affirm that this presence or its faith is of any use for salvation, but puts all in the faith by which Christ is believed to have died for us, how great an error is this, I ask? " Do you think this error should be forgiven? And yes, we would forgive it, if we ever found anything of sincere candour in this man, if he did not take advantage of our indulgence, yes, if it were permissible to forgive this through the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to invent another presence than that which is handed down by Scripture? What promises of God will he cite about a bodily presence? But why was it necessary to devise a bodily status, and finally to invent another faith with the sophists, other than that which is salvific? If he confesses that all his own inventions about which we are currently discussing do not contribute to salvation, he is certainly arguing for nothing, but has condemned us with a faithless and most impious judgement, indeed has mocked the Church of God until now. For if eating of the flesh does not profit, why does he keep drawing the thread of contention? Why does he pursue, exile and advise those who teach this? Is this the sincerity of a theologian, to cover the light of truth with darkness, to hide impostures in an open matter and to tie knots in Christian simplicity, and all this for the sake of contention and arrogance? Have we forgotten what the poet said: "the truth has a simple mouth, but the dishonest word needs the wisdom of the wise to heal it", or that most sacred saying of Paul: "Do not I think according to the flesh, that there be with me what is good, even though it be that which is not? But I truly testify before God, that our word to you was not yes and no. For the son of God who was preached among you by us, was not yes and no; but in him was yes. For all the promises of God in him are yes, and in him Amen, to the glory of God by us" [2 Cor 1:17-19]. "For we are not like many, who corrupt the word of God; but as of sincerity, but as of God, in the sight of God, we speak in Christ" [2 Cor 2:17]?

What then do we make of one who thinks, but he does not wish to think, or what do we force on him, I pray, of the Devil, who has previously delivered himself up to the Devil, if he should begin to think, as you preach of him? And what of this very same letter of yours: "If he were to believe and teach concerning the Eucharist, from the promise of God, a certain corporal presence of Christ over it, which inserts itself into our minds, yet at the same time he openly confesses that neither this presence nor this faith is of any avail for salvation, but that he places all in that faith by which Christ is believed to have died for us; what great error, I pray, do you think he is to be excused of? And, surely, we would excuse it, if ever we had found any sincerity in this man, if he did not abuse our indulgence, nay, if it were lawful to excuse it by the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to feign another presence than that which is delivered by the scriptures? What promises of God will he cite concerning the corporal presence? But what was the need of a corporal presence, or of inventing, in fine, another faith with the sophists than that which is salutary? But if he confesses that all his fictions, of which we now dispute, do nothing for salvation, certainly he contends for nothing, but has by an unrighteous and impious judgement condemned us, nay, has mocked the Church of God hitherto; for if flesh eaten profiteth nothing, why doth he pursue those that teach it, drive them into exile, and advise them to be slain? Is this the sincerity of a theologian, to envelop the light of truth with darkness, to hide impostures in an open matter, and to tie knots in Christian simplicity, and to do all this out of a spirit of contention and pride? Hath it escaped us what the poet said, "The tongue of truth is plain, but the dishonest word needs the skill of wise physicians," or that most sacred saying of Paul's, "Do I think according to the flesh, that there should be with me what is yes, yes and what is no, no? But I call God for a record, that to you-ward our conversation was not yes, yes, and no, no. For the Son of God, who was preached among you by us, was not yes, yes, and no, no; but in him was yea. For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us?"[2 Cor. 1:17-19]. "For we are not as many, which corrupt the word of God; but as of sincerity, but as of God, in the sight of God speak we in Christ."[2 Cor. 2:17]. What then do you advise should be considered by all the Church of Christ? Judge you, most dear Bucer, whether it be the part of a Church to yield to a kind of tenebrous person, to connive at his impostures, to suffer him to impose on the simpler sort by a cover of words, to lead about the more discreet, and so to mock the Church of God, the holy spouse of Christ, in the sight of God; and all this to be done, lest he should seem to confess a certain error pointed out?

seg.output: Saul indeed yielded to David, but in matters pertaining to the worldly kingdom and to his own body.We are in the church, which is the kingdom of Christ and truth, which relies on true faith and pure simplicity, is guided by them, and is preserved by them.If this is dear to Luther, he will certainly not know any other faith but the saving one, but he will not involve even Christian simplicity in controversy.Do you think that the contentious steersman should yield if his moroseness can be borne without danger to the ship's badge, so that the ship does not perish altogether through contention?But this meanwhile, my Bucer, is in dispute, whether Luther's moroseness and intolerable pride, his also sharp wit against the best, and more than rapid fury, his lust for the sacrosanct truth and simplicity, with which he pins and repins, enfolds and perverts things according to his pleasure, can be borne without detriment to the truth; or, whether it is proper for the good to navigate in the same ship and connive at the steersman's drunkenness, temerity and wickedness, from which afterwards a capital danger may arise for all the good.And you say: "Is it not better to bear this than that anyone should make such a necessity of the ceremonies of Moses, that he should not think Christ sufficient without their observance?"But what, my Bucer, if I bear neither of these, because the one altogether evacuates Christ, and the other is contrary to acknowledged truth, and not only contrary, but also with singular impudence dares to demand that the whole world swear by his words, and use none other than those which he himself is wont to use?

seg.output: Saul indeed yielded to David, but with regard to matters pertaining to the worldly kingdom and to his own body. We are in the church, which is the kingdom of Christ and of truth, which is founded on true faith and pure simplicity, which is guided and preserved by these. If this is agreeable to Luther, he surely will not know any other faith but the saving one, but he will not involve even this Christian simplicity in webs. Do you think, my Bucer, that if the captain's moroseness can be borne without endangering the ship's insignia, it should be yielded in order not to have the whole ship perish through contention? But in the meantime, my Bucer, a controversy has arisen, whether Luther's moroseness and intolerable pride, his also sharp and biting wit towards the best of men, his more than rapid frenzy, and his libidinousness for sacred truth and simplicity, by which he fastens and refastens, envelops and perverts things according to his own will, can be borne without detriment to truth, or whether it is proper for the good to navigate in the same ship and wink at the captain's drunkenness, rashness, and knavery, from which the imminent danger of death may afterwards arise to all the good. And you, indeed, say, "Would it not be better to bear this, than that one should make such a necessity of the ceremonies of Moses, as not to think that Christ is enough without their observance?" But what, my Bucer, if I bear neither this nor that, for the one entirely evacuates Christ, and the other is opposed to acknowledged truth, and not only is opposed, but also with singular impudence dares to demand that the whole world should swear by his words, and not use any other than what he himself uses? "But Paul bore that error," you say, "and not only bore it, but also confirmed himself an observer of ceremonies by deed." But you appear to me here, Bucer, to see what Paul bore, why he bore it, and how long he bore it. But I find far otherwise in the Acts, chapter 15 [1-21] and especially in the Galatians, chapter 2 [11-21], where he openly resists Peter in the face of Judaizing and after a few words subjoins these words: "If then I build up again those things which I have destroyed, I make myself a transgressor" [Gal 2:18], and again: "Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing" etc. [Gal 5:2]. Behold, what could be said more plainly? What more lively than what he wrote to the Hebrews? What then shall we say? That which heretics, if Tertullian speaks truly, said the apostles taught one thing to one and another to another? But this opinion, as being most false, has long been cast out of the theater of Christ.

The downfall of King Saul indeed happened, but in matters concerning the worldly kingdom and his own body. We in the church are the kingdom of Christ and truth, which is based on true faith and pure simplicity, guided by them and preserved by them. If these are the heart of Luther, he will not know any other faith but the salvific one, but he will not involve it in trifles. Do you think that the quarreling helmsman should yield, so that the whole ship may not perish in contention, if it is possible to bear his morosity without the danger of the ship's insignia? But in the meantime, my Bucer, the question arises, whether Luther's morosity and intolerable pride, his sharp comments on the best of people, his more than rapid frenzy, and his lust for the sacrosanct truth and simplicity, with which he fixes and refixes, twists and perverts things as he pleases, can be borne without detriment to the truth, or whether it is right for the good to sail in the same ship and to connive at the helmsman's drunkenness, recklessness and wickedness, from which later on the good may be exposed to great danger. And you say: "Would it not be worse to bear him than if someone made such a necessity out of the ceremonies of Moses, that without observing them one would not consider Christ to be enough?" But what, my Bucer, if I bear neither him nor the other, since the former completely evacuates Christ, while the latter is in conflict with the acknowledged truth, and not only in conflict, but also dares with singular impudence to demand that the whole world swear by his words and use none other than those that he himself uses? "But Paul bore this mistake," you say, "and not only bore it, but also proved himself to be an observer of the ceremonies by his deeds." But here, Bucer, it seems to me that you do not see what Paul has borne, why he has borne it, and for how long. For I find quite different things in the Acts 15 [1-21] and especially in the Galatians 2 [11-21], where he openly resists Peter's Judaizing even to his face and, after a few words, adds the following words: "For if I build again the things which I destroyed, I make myself a transgressor" [Gal 2,18], and again: "Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing" etc. [Gal 5,2]. Behold, what could be said more clearly? What more vividly than what he wrote to the Hebrews? What then shall we say? That the heretics, if Tertullian reports it correctly, have taught the apostles something different from each other? But this opinion, as being most false, has already been cast out of the theatre of Christ long ago. For even if Paul has become all things to all men, his teaching of Christ has always remained the same. As far as the only example of purification is concerned, we know that there is a different reason for the deed and a different law.

For he, having been caught in logomachy and vanity, yields neither to the truth nor ceases to set out new quarrelsome webs.

seg.output: You, who move no stone unturned, once again say: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. And those who doubt that they are Christ's, have never preached the gospel with any real success." But you always omit, dear Bucer, whose fault it is that we are not one. Certainly not ours. For on our part stands the constant truth and Christian simplicity, which cannot be forsaken by us with a safe and healthy conscience. So Luther's fault is why we do not agree. For being rebuked for his sophistry and vanity, he does not yield to the truth, nor does he cease to lay down new weaving for quarreling. So it is appropriate to him, not to us, what you say, that the gospel can not be preached with any real success by the dissenters. Therefore you seem to be justified and wise in putting Luther above all the doctors of the world. For if one looks at the desire to curse and talk, he would take the first place among the doctors, and Thersites would have the first place among the Greek heroes. But if one contemplates with a pure mind the restoration of piety, learned piety and sharp judgment in sacred things, indefatigable labor and the most experienced prudence, Luther will not even be able to offer a slipper to Capnio, Erasmus, Pellicanus, Oecolampadius or Zuinglio, the foremost men in the true religion.

You, who move no stone to reach your goal, again state: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. But those who doubt they are of Christ have never preached the gospel with any real benefit." But you, dear Bucer, always omit whose fault it is that we are not one. Certainly not ours; for on our side stands the constant truth and Christian simplicity that cannot be forsaken with a safe and sound conscience. Therefore, it is due to Luther that we do not agree, for he, being corrupted by logic-chopping and vain-glory, does not yield to truth nor cease to introduce new arguments of strife. So, it is to him, not us, that what you say applies: that the gospel can not be preached with any real benefit by those who dissent. And thus you seem to have good reason and wisdom to place Luther above all doctors of the world. For if one were to consider a love of cursing and talking, he would take first place among the learned and Thersites would have the chief place among the Greek heroes. But if one were to consider with a pure mind the restoration of piety, learned piety, a sharp judgement in sacred matters, an indefatigable labor, and a most experienced wisdom and constancy, Luther can not even be compared to Capnio, Erasmus, Pellican, Oecolampadius, or Zuinglius, who were the foremost men in true religion. Why, then, do we linger with them? Why do we still look to persons? Paul had already seen this long ago and it should have been clear to us: "May it not be laid to their charge, who were some time what they were: but God hath made him unto us wisdom, and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption."

seg.output: But you, who moves no stone unturned, again throw out: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. And those who doubt whether they are Christ's, never preached the gospel with any fruitful result." But you constantly omit, my dearest Bucere, whose fault it is that we are not one. Certainly not ours. For on our side stands the constant truth and Christian simplicity which cannot be deserted by us with a safe and sound conscience. Therefore Luther's fault is the cause why we do not agree. For he, being attacked by sophistry and empty pride, neither yields to truth nor ceases to lay down new threads of contention. Therefore it is fitting that, not us, you should say that the gospel can not be preached by the dissenters with any fruitful result. Therefore it appears to be right and proper for you to prefer Luther to all the teachers in the world. For if, to speak freely with you, one considers the zeal for cursing and talking, he would take the first place among the doctors and Thersites would have the chief place among the Greek heroes. But if one with a pure mind contemplates the restoration of piety, the pious learning and an acute judgement in sacred matters, an indefatigable labour and an exercised constancy and prudence, then Luther will not be able to offer even a straw to Capnion, Erasmus, Pellican, Oecolampadius or Zuinglio, the principal men of true religion. Why then do we linger with these? Why do we still look at persons? To whom the saying of Paul, long since understood, should be applicable: "Those who seemed to be something - whatever they had been at one time - it made no difference to me. God does not accept man's person - those who seemed to be in estimation, nothing availed me" [Gal 2:6], and again: "What then is Paul, and what Apollos, but ministers by whom you believed, and to each one as the Lord gave?" [1 Cor 3:4f.7].

seg.output: You, who move every stone, repeat again: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. And those who doubt that they are of Christ, will never preach the gospel with good fruit". But you perpetually omit, dearest Bucer, whose fault it is that we are not one. Certainly not ours. For from our side stands constant truth and Christian simplicity, which cannot be forsaken by us with safe and sound conscience. Therefore, Luther's fault is the cause of our discordance. For, corrupted by logomachy and vain-glory, he neither yields to truth nor ceases to lay new quarreling threads into the midst. Therefore, it fits to him, not to us, what you say, that from dissenders the gospel can not be preached with any good fruit. Therefore, you appear to have placed Luther before all teachers in the world with what right and counsel. For, if one should consider the study of reviling and babbling, then Luther will hold the first place among the teachers, and Thersites would have obtained the principal place among the Greek heroes. But if one should contemplate pure-heartedly the restoration of piety, pious learning and a sharp judgement in holy matters, an indefatigable effort and an utmost wise and constant fortitude, then neither Capnion, nor Erasmus, nor Pellican, nor Oecolampadius, nor Zuinglius, chief men in true religion, will be able to give Luther a rival. What then do we linger with these? Why do we still look to persons? To whom that of Paul's was already long since evident: "Those who seemed to be something - whatever they were, it matters not to me. God takes no man's person - to me, who seemed to be of some importance, they imparted nothing" [Gal 2,6], and again: "What then is Apollos? What is Paul? Ministers through whom you believed, and to each one as the Lord gave" [1 Cor 3,4f.7]. As for the progress and increase of the Lutheran churches, we know that the day of the Lord will declare what is the work of each. We, meanwhile, know that the doctrine of Arius and Mohammed was almost dispersed through the whole East, though we do not yet fully compare Luther with them.

You again, who leaves no stone unturned, press the point: "Those who are not one, are not of Christ. But those who are unsure of their Christianity, have never preached the gospel with any real fruit." But, dearest Bucer, you constantly overlook whose fault it is that we are not one. It is certainly not ours - our side is held by a constant truth and Christian simplicity, which cannot be forsaken by us with a safe and sound conscience. So, it is Luther's fault that we do not agree. For he, being corrupted by logomachy and empty boasting, neither yields to truth nor ceases to bring forth new quarrelsome webs. Therefore, it is him, and not us, that is fitting with what you say, that the gospel cannot be preached with any real fruit from those who dissent. Therefore, you seem to show by what right and counsel Luther is preferred to all the teachers in the world. For if we consider the study of reviling and garrulity, he will take the highest place among teachers, and Thersites would have the chief place among the Greek heroes. But if one looks upon with a pure mind the restoration of piety, learned piety, a keen judgment in sacred matters, indefatigable labor, and an extremely experienced prudence, Luther will not be able to offer even a morsel to Capnion, Erasmus, Pellican, Oecolampadius, and Zuinglius, who were the main men in the true religion. Why then do we linger here? Why do we still look at the persons? It should have been long ago clear to them, according to Paul's words: "Those who seemed to be something - whatever they were, brings nothing to me. God does not accept a man's person - to me, those who seemed to be of importance, nothing contributed" [Gal 2:6], and again: "What then is Apollos? What is Paul? Servants through whom you believed, and to each, the Lord has given something. It is not the one who plants or waters, but the one who gives the increase, who is God" [1 Cor 3:4f.7]. As far as the progress and increase of Lutheran churches is concerned, we know that the day of the Lord will declare what the work of each one is. Meanwhile we know that the doctrine of Arius and Mohammed was dispersed almost throughout the whole Orient, though we do not yet altogether compare Luther to them. We speak of the increase and consent of churches.
Now you ask, how then shall we repel this evil from us? Certainly without any loss of truth. For it is better for us to bear this evil with our own evil for a longer time than to make a badly patched peace with a man who prefers to have all glory given to himself than to truth. "Shall you then repay evil with evil?" I do not think so. For we have not been accustomed to do this so far. For whenever adversaries have thrown such thunderbolts at us, which neither the glory of God and faith nor the ministry of the Word advised to ignore, they have been so modestly extinguished that we have not dealt with any of them according to their worth.

seg.output: You are asking here how we will repel this evil from us. Certainly no loss of truth. For it is better to endure this evil of ours for a longer time than to make a badly woven peace with a man who prefers himself to having all glory given to truth. "So will you repay insult with insult?" I do not think so. For we have not been used to that until now. For whenever our adversaries have hurled such thunderbolts at us which neither the glory of God and faith nor the ministry of the word advised us to hide, we have nevertheless been so modest that we have not treated any of these with due respect. So let us be modest even now, and whenever the glory of God and the advantage of our churches suggest it, we shall defend the business of truth in the present case and other necessary matters not only against Luther but also against all enemies, disturbers and perverters of truth with such forces as divine grace will supply us with. But you will not gain anything "with those" you say "for whom defence was to be approved". You are asking here how we will repel this evil from us. Certainly no loss of truth. For it is better to endure this evil of ours for a longer time than to make a badly woven peace with a man who prefers himself to having all glory given to truth. "So will you repay insult with insult?" I do not think so. For we have not been used to that until now. For whenever our adversaries have hurled such thunderbolts at us which neither the glory of God and faith nor the ministry of the word advised us to hide, we have nevertheless been so modest that we have not treated any of these with due respect. So let us be modest even now, and whenever the glory of God and the advantage of our churches suggest it, we shall defend the business of truth in the present case and other necessary matters not only against Luther but also against all enemies, disturbers and perverters of truth with such forces as divine grace will supply us with. But you will not gain anything "with those" you say "for whom defence was to be approved". This did not come to us first, but even to the greatest and most holy men from the very beginning of the world. For neither the prophets nor the apostles, even with their most loving writings, gained anything with the enemies of truth.

For it is more advantageous for us to bear this evil longer than to make a badly patched peace with a man who would prefer that all glory be given to himself rather than to truth. Nor do we in the meantime ignore what and how the ancients spoke. Further, if it is corporally in the right hand of the Father and in the supper at the same time and once, the body of Christ is infinite. But what of many? We will prove this to be true and now promise you that we will receive Luther as a most beloved brother, as soon as he has given all glory to the truth, those most holy and worthy men of the Church of Christ, even those who follow our doctrine of the Eucharist, or rather, not ours, but God's, whether it be Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or some other, and that he has ceased to bite and persecute, to envelop simplicity in clouds, to pervert the right, to carry off pure things craftily, to write jagged papers and famous, as they say, pamphlets, to speak evil, to calumniate and to proclaim the heretics and false prophets.

seg.output: What is more to many? We have not learned, dearest Bucer, to sit on two chairs. If the body of Christ is physically at the right hand of God, surely it is not physically at the table. Meanwhile, we do not ignore what and how the ancients spoke. Furthermore, if it is physically both at the right hand of the Father and at the table at the same time, the body of Christ is infinite. What is infinite, however, is not a body. Therefore, the body of Christ is not a body. Indeed, Elijah cried out: "How long will you go limping between two opinions?" [1 Kings 18:21] Paul also cries out: "What agreement has the light with the darkness?" [2 Corinthians 6:14] And all antiquity cried out: "Straight and clear are the just!"Now we bear witness to God that we do not envy the glory of Luther, as much as God has given him, nor do we wish to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do it out of love for truth and simplicity. seg.output: What then of many? We have not learned, dearest Bucer, to sit on two chairs. If the body of Christ is bodily at the right hand of God, then it is certainly not bodily at the table. Nor, in the meantime, do we ignore what and how the ancients have spoken. Moreover, if the body of Christ is bodily at the right hand of the Father and at the table at the same time and once, the body of Christ is infinite. But what is infinite is not a body. Therefore, the body of Christ is not a body. Now Elijah shouted: "How long will you go limping between the two?" [1 Kön 18.21] Paul also cries out: "What fellowship has light with darkness?" [2 Cor 6.14] And all antiquity cried out: "Simple and clear are the rights." We now bear witness to God that we do not begrudge Luther the glory that God has given him, nor do we want to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do it out of love for truth and simplicity. We will prove this to be so in this matter and now promise you that as soon as Luther has given all glory to the truth, we will receive him as our closest brother, the holy and well-deserving men of the Church of Christ, and even our own, no, not our own, but God's, those who follow the dogma of the Eucharist, the innocent, be it Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or someone else, stop biting and persecuting, wrapping simplicity in clouds, perverting what is right, bringing out what is pure in a captious way, writing jagged papers and famous, as they say, leaflets, cursing, slandering and proclaiming heretics or superstitious prophets. These things will not be burdensome to him, but he will do them willingly and of his own accord, provided that he is in agreement with us in our opinion. If not, we would rather hear from the turbulent multitude of Lutherans than be called hypocrites by all the saints in both reality and name. For we had once established, and will now perform by the grace of God, that we will dedicate our life to holy truth and pious simplicity, yielding to no one unless "something better is revealed to him who is seated" [1 Cor 14.30]. "The time that remains to us is short" [1 Cor 7.29], the inconstant world, more inconstant men, timid and fearful of the holy cross of God.

seg.output:
What is it to many of us? We have not learned, my dear Bucere, to sit on two chairs. If the body of Christ is bodily to the right hand of God, certainly it is not bodily at the supper. And yet we do not ignore what and how the ancients have spoken. Moreover, if it is bodily to the right hand of the Father and at the same time at the supper, then the body of Christ is infinite. But that which is infinite is not a body. Therefore, the body of Christ is not a body. Indeed, Elijah cried out: "How long will you waver between two opinions?" [1 Kings 18:21] Paul cries out, too: "What agreement has the light with the darkness?" [2 Corinthians 6:14] And all antiquity cried out: "Plain and clear justice". But we testify to God that the glory that God has given to Luther we do not envy him, nor do we wish to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do it out of love for the truth and simplicity. We shall prove this to be so and we now promise you that we shall receive Luther as our dearest brother as soon as he has given all glory to the truth, and that he will cease to bite and persecute holy and excellent men who have deserved well of the Church of Christ, even those following our—rather, not our, but God's—doctrine on the Eucharist, innocent men, be they Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or another, that he will cease to cloud simplicity with fog, to pervert the straight, to bring out pure things in a captious manner, to write tooth-marked papers and famous, as they say, pamphlets, to revile, to calumniate, and to proclaim heretics or superstitious prophets. But these things will not be grievous to him, rather, he will most readily and of his own accord do so if he is of the same opinion as us, as you say. But if not, we would prefer to hear ill of the turbulent group of Lutherans than to be called hypocrites in actuality and in name by all the saints. For we have once determined and we shall do it through the grace of God that we shall devote our life to holy truth and pious simplicity, yielding to no one unless something better has been revealed to him who sits by. "The time that remains is short" [1 Corinthians 7:29], the world is inconstant, men more inconstant, fearful and trembling before the holy cross of God. But we do not want to be at any time noted by the Pauline sentence: "Whoever desires to please in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" etc. [Galatians 6:12].
Now, the fact that you allowed and even were authors of subscribing to the Saxon Confession in your public affairs, we do not wish to either approve or disapprove, since, as the saying goes, the deed is done and cannot be undone. Certainly we would never have done such a thing without consulting with you. But perhaps it was so ordained by God that we be once deprived of all human help and fellowship. But come, "let the will of the Lord be done" [Acts 21:14]. It is manifestly evident, and cannot be denied, that in that Confession are some things contrary to sincere doctrine, some things which we ourselves have formerly opposed and disapproved of, and some things which are fairly obscure and childish.

Certainly we would never have done such a thing without consulting you. However, perhaps it was ordained by God that once we be deprived of all human help and fellowship. Such is the assertion that the Holy Spirit is given through the sacraments as instruments, that faith is confirmed by them and that baptism is necessary for salvation. They speak of water baptism. Those things that are discussed concerning confession, absolution and mass are more widely known than to require repetition, and it is well known what they define concerning the Eucharist, which they have fully condemned, as did we. For whom have they condemned if not us?

seg.output: We do not wish to either approve or disapprove of your allowing, and even becoming the authors of subscribing to the Saxon Confession, as the proverb goes, an action once done cannot be undone. Certainly we would not have done such a thing without consulting you. But perhaps it has been ordained by God that we be once deprived of all human aid and fellowship. But anyway, "let the will of the Lord be done" [Acts 21:14]. It is more evident than can be denied that in this confession there are some things which are contrary to sincere doctrine, some which we ourselves have formerly attacked and disapproved, and some which are quite obscure and childish. Such is the doctrine that the Holy Spirit is given through the Sacraments as instruments, that faith is confirmed by them, and that baptism is necessary for salvation. They speak of baptism with water. But those things which are discussed concerning confession, absolution, and mass are better known than to need repeating, the most renowned being the definition of the Eucharist, which our own have altogether condemned. For whom have they condemned others if not us? Or how could it be that after so many excellent works of ours they have not yet rightly understood us? Zwingli wrote many things, Oecolampadius wrote much and with piety, Bucerus wrote, the confession of both sides was heard at Marpurg. And yet the impudent sentence of condemnation followed.

seg.output: We do not wish to either approve or disapprove of your taking part in, and even being the authors of, subscribing to the Saxon Confession, since, as the proverb says, “done is done” and cannot be undone. Indeed, had we acted without consulting you, we would never have done such a thing. But perhaps it was God’s will that, once and for all, we should be deprived of all human aid and fellowship. However, it is too obvious to be denied that there are some things in this confession which are contrary to sound doctrine, some which we ourselves have previously condemned and rejected, and some which are obscure and childlike. Such is the belief that the Holy Spirit is given and faith is confirmed through the sacraments as instruments, that baptism is necessary for salvation, and that they are speaking about baptism by water. As for what they say about confession, absolution and mass, it is more widely known than to need repeating. And it is well known what they have defined about the eucharist, which they have also completely condemned, for if they have condemned others, why have they not condemned us? Or how could it be that they have not yet fully understood our works, after so many outstanding ones? Zwingli wrote numerous works, Oecolampadius many holy ones, and even Bucerus, and the Marburg Colloquy heard the confessions of both sides. Yet a shameless condemnation followed. Moreover, then and now they said the same thing, for their doctrine has been constant. What is more, Zwingli himself wrote so clearly and so devoutly about the sacraments, indeed about the entire religion, in “To Charles” and “To the Rulers of Augusta”, that no one has ever written more clearly on this subject.

seg.output:
We do not want to either approve or disapprove of your public affairs, that you not only allowed, but were also the authors of subscribing to the Saxon Confession, since, as the saying goes, the deed is done and can't be undone. Of course, we would never have done something like this without consulting you first. But maybe it was so ordained by God, that once we are deprived of all human help and fellowship. But, "Let the will of the Lord be done" [Acts 21:14]. That is more than evident, that in that Confession there are some things that are contrary to sincere doctrine, some of which we have previously attacked and disapproved of, some are also quite obscure and childish. Such as the one, that the Holy Spirit is bestowed through the Sacraments as instruments, that faith is confirmed by them, and that baptism is necessary for salvation. And they speak of baptism with water. But those things which they speak of confession, absolution and mass, are better known and it's not necessary to repeat them, as is also well known the definition they made of the Eucharist. Which they have completely condemned of ours. For who have they condemned, if not us? Or how could it be, that after so many excellent works, they still hadn't understood ours properly? Zwingli had written many, and Oecolampadius had written many religious ones, and also Bucerus, and the Confession of both sides was heard at Marpurg. And yet, a shameless condemnation followed. Nor did they say anything different then than now. The same doctrine has always remained. What of it, that Zwingli himself wrote so lucidly and so religiously about the sacraments, and indeed about the whole religion, and "To Charles" and "To the princes assembled in Augsburg" that nobody ever wrote more clearly about this matter? But even then, no peace could be obtained from these contentious and arrogant people.
Nevertheless, the condemnation remained established, to which we now subscribe so quickly. From this subscription, this will emerge for us, which now is rolling on everyone's tongue among us, that both the good and the bad will accuse us of inconsistency. By which our authority of ministry will be put in danger, not in itself, but because we will seem, as new and timid people, to feel, believe and teach something different now than before, which is called different. But you say: "Let many think that we have departed from our opinion, I would rather have this said of me, than to have nothing of Christ, to tear apart the words of Christ, and to measure all things of God according to the flesh".

seg.output:
From this subscription, however, it will emerge that both the good and the bad among us will accuse us of inconstancy - something that is already being said by everyone. As a result, the authority of our ministry will be put in danger, not in itself, but because it seems that we are innovators and timid people, believing and teaching one thing before and something else now. But you say: "I would rather have people believe that I have departed from my opinion than to have nothing of Christ, to tear apart the words of Christ, and to measure all things of God according to the measure of the flesh". As if we, who do not subscribe to Luther or who have not wanted to agree until now, have nothing of Christ, tear apart his words and measure all things of God according to the measure of the flesh. We lament, Bucer, we lament greatly, and we detest your words, detest them more than can be said, and we would not have expected such a thing from our dearest brothers. If you have spoken such insults and curses of Lutherans, we are surprised that you have so quickly forgotten what the Lord said: "Blessed are you when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely for my sake" [Matthew 5:11]. We are also surprised that you still write to us about peace and agreement in dogma, when you still feel such atrocities against us.
Therefore, I, like Leo, admonish you, Bucer, dear, to act this play so that it does not end in black tragedy. For although you do not hesitate to say that Zwingli has opposed that these things be accepted by us until now, we do acknowledge that all misfortune, loss and evil is now blamed not only on the opponents but also on the man of holy memory, Zwingli, from our side - but we will not discuss this with what right now.

Si quid aliter sentitis, et hoc Deus vobis revelabit» [Phil 3,15].
I was so astonished by your letter written to Leo, most wise Bucer, that I could not help but offer these humble words of ours in response. I have no doubt that you will act in good faith with it, since it has been sent in friendship. Your entire letter revolves mainly around persuading us to subscribe to Luther or yield to him in the matter of the Eucharist; that is how you have subscribed to the Saxon doctrines. Before you begin, you should strive to obtain your own faith, since you allow Leo to abound in his own. I wouldn't have much opposition to this, provided that faith keeps to its own rule. We know, "faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God" (Romans 10:17). We also know from the apostle: "If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God" (1 Peter 4:11); "if anything is revealed to another who sits by, let the first keep silent" (1 Corinthians 14:30); "the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets" (1 Corinthians 14:32-33). For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace (1 Corinthians 14:33). And elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, be of this mind" (Philippians 3:15). If you have any other opinion, God will reveal it to you.

Tota autem epistola tua in hoc versatur potissimum, ut nobis persuadeas Luthero vel subscribamus vel cedamus in eucharistiae negotio; sic quidem vos dogmatis subscripsisse Saxonicis . Priusquam vero ordiaris , impetrare niteris, ut te tua fide frui liceat, quandoquidem Leonem sua abundare permittas. Cui equidem non multum repugnaverim, modo fides suam servet regulam. Scimus enim «fidem ex auditu esse, auditum autem per verbum dei» [Röm 10,17]. Scimus item ab apostolo scriptum esse: «Si quis loquitur, loquatur ut eloquia dei» [1 Petr 4,11]; «quodsi alii fuerit revelatum assidenti, prior taceat» [1 Kor 14,30]; «spiritus autem prophetis subiiciuntur. Non enim confusionis author est deus, sed pacis» [1 Kor 14,32f], et alibi: «Quotquot igitur perfecti sumus, hoc sentiamus. Quodsi quis aliud senserit, hoc quoque», nempe id, quod perfecti sentiunt, «revelabit deus, ita tamen, ut in eo, quod assequti sumus, idem sentiamus et in eadem regula procedamus» [Phil 3,15f]. seg.output: So I was amazed by your letter to Leo, the most learned Bucere, that I could not oppose our own whatever to yours. I have no doubt that you will make good use of them, since they were sent with a friendly spirit. Your letter mainly revolves around the fact that you would persuade us to subscribe or yield to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, just as you have subscribed to the Saxon dogmas. Before you begin, you try to get permission to enjoy your own faith, since you allow Leo to be abundant in his. To which I would not have much objected, as long as faith keeps its rule. We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God" [Romans 10:17]. We also know that the apostle wrote: "If anyone speaks, let them speak as the oracles of God" [1 Peter 4:11]; "but if something is revealed to another who is sitting by, let the first be silent" [1 Corinthians 14:30]; "But the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace" [1 Corinthians 14:32f], and elsewhere: "Therefore, let us who are perfect be thus minded. But if any other thinks differently, God will reveal it to that one, yet so that even what we have attained will remain with us" [Philippians 3:15f]. And so, if the faith, either yours, my Bucere, or of anyone else, is from the word of truth, we accept it, and if not, we decline it with modesty. So too in the matter of Luther.

seg.output: I was so amazed at your letter to Leo, most learned Bucer, that I could not help but oppose our own views to yours. I have no doubt that you will act wisely in this matter, since it came from a friendly spirit. The main purpose of your letter is to persuade us to subscribe or yield to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist; thus, you have subscribed to the Saxon doctrine. Before you start, try to get permission to enjoy your own faith, since you allow Leo to be abundant in his. To this I would not object much, provided his faith keeps its own rule. We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God" [Romans 10:17]. Nevertheless, to us it is the same God who works all in all" [Philippians 3:15f]. seg.output: I was so amazed at your letter written to Leon, most learned Bucer, that I could not help but offer up these meager thoughts of ours in response. I have no doubt that you will weigh them with a friend's spirit. Your letter as a whole concentrates on trying to persuade us to either subscribe to or concede to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, as you Saxons have already subscribed to a doctrine. Before you proceed, you endeavor to obtain permission to rely on your faith, since you allow Leon to abound in his. To this I would not have much objection, provided faith keeps to its rule. For we know that “faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God” [Rom 10:17]. We know, too, that the apostle has written: “If anyone speaks, let it be as the oracles of God” [1 Pet 4:11]; “if something is revealed to another who is sitting by, let the first be silent” [1 Cor 14:30]; “the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not a God of confusion but of peace” [1 Cor 14:32ff], and elsewhere: “Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this way. And if in anything you think differently, God will reveal this also to you. Nevertheless, what we have attained, let us walk by the same rule” [Phil 3:15ff]. And thus, whether it is your faith, my Bucer, or anyone else's that is based on the word of truth, we accept it; if not, we decline it modestly. And so it is in the matter of Luther. If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he is subject to the prophets; if he is subject to the prophets, he will confess the truth; and if he confesses the truth, all discord will be eliminated. But if he is not subject, but stirs up turmoil, he does not have the spirit of God, who is the author of peace, not of turmoil. Who then should subscribe to him? Paul does not want us to accept the weak out of a spirit of concord, but he says that the weak are led by God in such a way that they embrace what is perfect.

seg.output: I was so amazed by your letter to Leo, most learned Bucer, that I could not help but to respond to your arguments whatever they may be. I have no doubt that you will come to a good decision based on these conversations with a friend.Your letter mainly revolves around trying to persuade us to either subscribe or defer to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, as the Saxons have done with their dogma. Before proceeding, you must first obtain permission to be guided by your own faith, since you allow Leo to be guided by his. To this I would not object much, as long as faith observes its own rules. We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing by the word of God" [Romans 10:17]. We also know that the Apostle wrote: "If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God" [1 Peter 4:11]; "if anything is revealed to another who is sitting by, let the first keep silent" [1 Corinthians 14:30]; "but the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion but of peace" [1 Corinthians 14:32f], and elsewhere: "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this: and if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you. Nevertheless, whereto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule" [Philippians 3:15f]. Therefore, if the faith of you, my Bucer, or of anyone else is from the word of truth, we accept it, but we decline it with modesty if it is not. So too in the matter of Luther. If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he is subject to the prophets; and if he is subject to the prophets, he will certainly confess the truth, and if he confesses the truth, all disagreement will be dispelled. But if he is not subject to them, but rather stirring up the crowds, he does not have the spirit of God, who is the author of peace and not of disorder. Who then will subscribe to him? Paul does not want us to accept the weak in the name of concord, but rather through God's leading of the weak, so that they embrace what is more perfect. Now, it is up to you to explain what is more perfect in the Eucharist. So then, tell us, most learned Bucer, what kind of doctrine it is that we have attained from God in the Eucharist, in which we agree and follow the same rule: Luther's or ours?

Si Lutherus spiritum habet propheticum, prophetis subiicitur, porro, si prophetis subiicitur, veritatem plane fatebitur, hanc vero si confessus fuerit, sublata erit omnis discordia. seg.output: I was so amazed by your letter to Leon, most learned Bucer, that I could not help but oppose this weak response of ours. I am sure that you will act wisely in this matter, since it came from a friendly spirit. The main purpose of your letter is to persuade us to either subscribe to or yield to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, as you have subscribed to the Saxon doctrine. Before you begin, you should try to secure that you may enjoy your faith, since you have allowed Leon to abound in his. To this I would not have much objection, as long as faith keeps its own rule. We know that “faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God” (Rom 10:17). We also know that it has been written by the apostle: “If anyone speaks, let him speak as the oracles of God” (1 Pet 4:11); “if anything is revealed to another who sits by, let the first keep silent” (1 Cor 14:30); “but the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion but of peace” (1 Cor 14:32-33), and elsewhere: “Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this: and if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal even this to you. Nevertheless, to us God has revealed them through the Spirit. For the Spirit searches all things, yes, the deep things of God. For ‘who has known the mind of the Lord that he may instruct Him?’ But we have the mind of Christ” (Phil 3:15-16). Therefore, if the faith, whether it is yours, my Bucer, or of anyone else, is from the word of truth, we accept it; otherwise, we decline it with modesty. So it is with Luther’s matter. If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he is subject to the prophets; and if he is subject to the prophets, he will certainly confess the truth; and if he confesses the truth, all discord will be removed. But if he does not yield, but stirs up the people, he does not have the spirit of God, who is the author of peace, not of confusion. So who will subscribe to him? Paul certainly does not want to receive the weak for the sake of peace, but he says that the weak should be led by God so that they may embrace what is perfect. Now it is up to you, most learned Bucer, to explain what is perfect in the Eucharist. Therefore, tell us what kind of doctrine it is that we have obtained from God in the Eucharist, in which we agree and proceed in the same rule, is it Luther’s or ours? Certainly Luther’s dogma is weaker, as your books prove, so ours is perfect. For if it is the same opinion of both of us, what are you working for peace, which is otherwise obtained by the consent of truth?

I was so astonished at your letter, learned Bucer, written to Leo, that I could not help but respond with our own thoughts. I am sure that you will act wisely, as these words come from the heart of a friend. Your letter mainly revolves around convincing us to subscribe or yield to Luther in the matter of the Eucharist, just as the Saxons have done. Before you begin, you try to get permission to enjoy your own faith, since you grant Leo permission to rely on his. I would not have opposed this much, provided his faith retains its rule. We know that "faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of God" [Romans 10:17]. We also know that the apostle has written, "If anyone speaks, let them speak as the oracles of God" [1 Peter 4:11], "if a revelation has been given to another who is seated, let the first be silent" [1 Corinthians 14:30], "the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. For God is not the author of confusion but of peace" [1 Corinthians 14:32-33], and elsewhere, "Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, think this. And if anyone thinks differently, God will reveal even this to him. Nevertheless, let us follow the same rule" [Philippians 3:15-16]. And so, if the faith of either mine, Bucer, or of anyone else is from the word of truth, we accept it; if not, we decline it modestly. So too in Luther's affair. If Luther has a prophetic spirit, he is subject to the prophets, and if he is subject to the prophets, he will surely confess the truth; and if he confesses the truth, all discord will be eliminated. But if he is not subject to the prophets, but instead stirs up riots, he does not have the spirit of God, who is the author of peace, not of riots. So who will subscribe to him? Certainly Paul does not want us to accept something weaker for the sake of agreement, but he says the weak should be led by God to accept what is more perfect. Now tell us, learned Bucer, what kind of doctrine it is that we have received from God in the Eucharist, in which we agree and follow the same rule—Luther's or ours? Certainly Luther's dogma is weaker, as your own books convince us, so ours must be more perfect. For if their views are the same, what labor are you putting into achieving agreement, which otherwise would be achieved through mutual consent of the truth? But if they are different and ours is more perfect and his weaker, why are you calling us to agreement, to which Paul did not call?
But you say, "I know from words and writings that nothing is given by words or sacraments but the admonition and exercise of the mind to faith." Oh that it were so, and Luther himself would freely confess what you are forcing on those who are unwilling. You would earnestly wish Luther to speak, think, and understand his own words in this way. And perhaps he would if you appealed to him peacefully rather than contentiously. But he does not wish to be so. For if he ever did, you would not have wasted so much labor in vain in trying to reconcile, which you yourself admit, having been frustrated time and again by written dialogue and conversations held in Marburg, Augsburg, and Coburg.

seg.output: As Leo has warned you, my dearest Bucere, I too warn you to conduct this affair in such a manner that it does not end in a black tragedy. For although you may speak without exaggeration that Zuinglius opposed our doctrines, yet those who could not withstand them admitting more serious matters, we do indeed acknowledge that the blame for every misfortune, loss and evil is now thrown not only on the adversaries but also on the memory of the pious Zuinglius from our own ranks. But we shall not argue now by what right. We do not know what more our own people have admitted, since nothing has yet departed from our solid and sincere doctrine. But this we know for certain, that all who were in Asia have been averse to the glory of God and to the doctrine of truth, without Paul the Apostle being injured. We know also that he has said: “All who will live piously in Christ will suffer persecution,” and “But the solid foundation of God stands firm, having this seal: ‘The Lord knows those who are His,’ and let everyone who calls upon the name of Christ depart from iniquity” (2 Tim. 2:19). We know also that he said: “But evil men and impostors will go on to worse, leading astray and being led astray” (2 Tim. 3:12f). So, my dearest Bucere, I urge you to conduct this affair so that it does not end in a black tragedy. Do not too easily yield to Luther nor believe him.

seg.output: What Leo has warned you, dearest Bucer, I too warn you: deal with this matter so it does not end in a dark tragedy. For although you say without exaggeration that Zwingli has opposed the fact that these things have not been accepted by us so far, we do concede that now indeed the blame for every misfortune, loss and evil is rejected not only from the opponents but also from our own Zwingli, of blessed memory. But which justice, we will not discuss now. We do not know what worse thing our own people have done, since nothing has yet departed from the solid and sincere doctrine among us. But this we know very well, that all who were in Asia have rejected Paul the Apostle without injury to the glory of God and the doctrine of truth. We know also that he said: “all those who wish to live piously in Christ, must suffer persecution. But wicked men and impostors shall grow worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived” [2 Tim 3,12f] and again: “But the firm foundation of God stands, having this seal: ‘The Lord knows those who are his own’, and let everyone who invokes the name of Christ depart from iniquity” [2 Tim 2,19]. Therefore we pray, dearest brother, through the Lord Jesus Christ, that you look closer at this matter, do not yield too much to Luther and do not believe him. He is like a scorpion: if you observe him with all your effort, he will still sting you, even if he appears to lick at the beginning. We also pray that you follow us with the same love with which we truly embrace you. I wanted to pour out this surge of my soul to you, as a special friend and dearest brother, indeed as a preceptor.
