seg.output:
Wir söllend das heylige wort gotts nicht aufgeben oder verändern, sondern es treybiglich erhalten und beförderen, damit es ewig werde, und eß nicht verkehrt oder schändlich werde».
What Leo warned you about, my dearest Bucere, I too warn you, that you handle this play in such a way that it does not end in a dark tragedy. For although you don't say without emphasis that Zwingli opposed our acceptance of these things thus far, we recognize, nevertheless, that now, indeed, all misfortune, loss and evil is blamed not only on the adversaries, but also on the memory of the holy man Zwingli from our own side, but we will not debate on what right. But we do not know what our people have admitted more severely, since nothing has yet departed from the solid and sincere doctrine among us. But this we do know for certain, that all who were in Asia opposed Paul the apostle without injury to the glory of God and the doctrine of truth. Therefore, my dearest brother, we pray through our Lord Jesus Christ, that you look closer into this matter, and do not concede too much to Luther, nor believe him. We from Bern, from the city and countryside, likewise some from Solodorn and the Biel brothers, bishops, have written to the Tigurine rulers with this opinion: "We have unanimously advised and agreed amongst ourselves, disregarding the agreement of Luther and Strasbourg, by the holy word of God which we have accepted and preached until now, to remain steadfast and unchanged. We should not abandon or alter the holy word of God, but hold and promote it faithfully, so that it may be everlasting and not be wronged or dishonored."
Henry Bullinger, who, together with Leo, has earnestly beseeched you in this matter, salutes you, as do also Pellicanus, Theodore, Carolstadius, and Erasmus Fabritius, who all share the same opinion with us.

[!] iulii 1532.»
Memineris, Bucere, istius tuae pollicitationis et subscriptionis, quam senatus populusque Bernensis scripto de vobis habet.
Martino Bucero, fratri charissimo.
seg.output:
Recently, citizens of Bern both from the city and the countryside, some from Solothurn, as well as the Biel bishops, sent this message to the Tigurinus leaders: “We have discussed and unanimously decided, regardless of the agreement between Luther and Strasbourg, to remain loyal to Luther’s holy word of God, as we have defended and preached it until now, to remain unchanged and undisturbed. Therefore, we earnestly ask you to remain faithful to it in accordance with your orders. We will await with anticipation what God will do with us, etc. Dated in Zofingen during our gathering, 8 July 1532.”
Remember, Martin Bucer, this promise and subscription which the Bernese Senate and people have in writing from you.
To Martin Bucer, dearest brother.

seg.input: Sed dicis: «Scio ex verbis et scriptis, quod nihil vel verbis vel sacramentis tribuat quam admonitionem et exercitationem animi ad fidem». Atque utinam sic haberet res, ipseque Lutherus id, quod nolenti obtrudis, libere confiteretur. Tu quidem impense velles Lutherum sic loqui, sic sentire, sic sua ipsius verba intelligere. Et fortassis faceret, si a contentioso appellares ad tranquillum. Sed talis esse non vult. Nam si unquam voluisset, tu non tot laboris in concordia sarcienda frustra insumpsisses, id quod ipse fateris, te infecta re subinde frustratum dialogo scripto, colloquiis item Marpurgi , Augustae et Koburgi habitis . Quid igitur aliud sentientem facimus, quam ipse sentiat aut sentire velit? Quid eum, oro, sathanae obtrudimus, qui sese prius dęmoni tradidit, si ita, ut tu de eo praedicas, sentire coeperit? Quid, quod tu ipse in hac ipsa tua epistola: «Si circa eucharistiam», inquis, «credat et doceat ex promissione dei statui corporalem quandam Christi praesentiam supra eam, qua se nostris mentibus inserit, cum tamen nec praesentiam hanc nec eius fidem cuiquam saluti esse diserte fateatur, sed omnia in ea fide collocet, qua creditur Christum pro nobis mortuum, quantus, queso, error?». Hunc tu illi errorem censes condonandum. Et sane condonaremus, si unquam candidae synceritatis in hoc homine invenissemus quicquam, si is non abuteretur indulgentia nostra, imo, si hoc per veritatis simplicitatem condonare liceret. And would that it were so, and Luther himself would freely confess what you want him to accept against his will. Indeed, you would wish Luther to speak, think and understand his own words in this way. And perhaps he would do so if you called him away from contentiousness to tranquillity. What of the fact that you yourself say in this very same letter of yours: "If he believes and teaches about the Eucharist, from the promise of God, a certain corporeal presence of Christ above it, by which he inserts himself into our minds, yet at the same time affirms that neither this presence nor this faith is of any benefit to salvation, but rather places all in that faith by which Christ is believed to have died for us - what great error, I ask, do you consider this to be pardonable? And indeed we would pardon it if ever we found any candour of sincerity in this man, if he were not to take advantage of our indulgence, nay, if it were possible to pardon it through the simplicity of truth. For what need is there to invent another presence other than the one handed down in the Scriptures? What promises of God will he cite for us concerning a corporeal presence? But why was it necessary to posit a corporeal presence, indeed to devise a faith with the sophists different from the saving one? But if he acknowledges that all his figments, about which we are now debating, are of no benefit to salvation, then he is certainly fighting over nothing, but has also judged us with a faithless and impious judgement, nay, has up to now mocked the church of God. For if eating flesh is of no benefit, why does he drag on this rope of contention perpetually? Why does he pursue those who teach it, drive them into exile and advise to have them killed? Or is this the sincerity of a theologian, to cover the light of truth with darkness, to hide impostures in a plain matter, and to weave snares in Christian simplicity, and all this with the spirit of contention and arrogance?

You say: “I know from words and writings that nothing gives more than admonition and exercise of the mind to faith, either by words or sacraments.” And oh that it were so, and that Luther himself would freely confess what you are unwilling to impose upon him. Certainly you would earnestly wish Luther to speak, think and understand his own words in this manner. And perhaps he would, if you called him away from contentiousness to tranquility. But he does not wish to be so. For if he had ever wished to, you would not have spent so much labour in vain upon patching up agreement, as you yourself admit, being so often disappointed by written discourse, and also by conversations held at Marpurg, Augsburg and Coburg. What then do we think of one who is of this opinion, but that he thinks and wishes to think as he does? What do we thrust upon him, I pray, of Satan's, who has already surrendered himself to the devil, if he should begin to think, as you preach of him? What, that in this very letter of yours you say: “If he believes and teaches concerning the eucharist, out of God's promise, a certain corporeal presence of Christ above it, wherein He inserts Himself into our minds; whereas yet he confesses that neither this presence nor this faith is of any service to salvation, but places all in that faith whereby Christ is believed to have died for us: what great error, I beseech you, do you call this?” Do you think this error to be pardonable in him? And indeed we would pardon it, if we had ever found anything of candid sincerity in this man, if he did not abuse our indulgence, nay, if it were pardonable by the simplicity of truth. For what need is there of feigning any other presence but that which is delivered in Scripture? What promises of God will he cite concerning corporeal presence? But what need was there of framing a corporeal presence, and lastly of inventing a faith with the sophists, which should be salvific? But if he confesses that all his own fictions, about which we are now disputing, are of no service to salvation, he certainly contends for nothing, but has condemned us in a wicked and impious judgment, nay, has mocked the Church of God hitherto. For if flesh eaten profiteth nothing, why does he drag on this string of contention? Why does he pursue those that teach it, banish them into exile, and advise to put them to death? Or is this the sincerity of a theologian, to cover the light of truth with darkness, to hide impostures in an open matter, and to entangle snares in Christian simplicity, and all to do it for the sake of contention and arrogance? Or have we forgotten that which the poet said: “The simple man is born for the truth, but the unjust man needs the healing drugs of wise physicians”, or that most sacred saying of Paul: “Do I think according to the flesh, that there should be with me the same thing, yea, yea, and nay, nay? But I testify by God, that our speech toward you was not yea, and nay.”

Therefore, you advise to consider the whole Church of Christ, judge yourself, Bucer, dearest, whether it is the Church's way to agree with a dark man, to connive at his impostures, to allow him to impose on those who are simpler by the veil of words, to encircle the more reasonable, and to thus ridicule the entire Church of God, the holy bride of Christ, in the sight of God, and to do all this, lest he should seem to confess the designated error.
David yielded to Saul, but in matters pertaining to the worldly kingdom and to his own body. We are in the Church, which is the kingdom of Christ and truth, which relies on true faith and pure simplicity, is led by them, and is preserved by them. If these things are dear to Luther, he will certainly not know any other faith than the saving one, but will not involve the Christian simplicity itself in snares. seg.output: Indeed Saul gave way to David, but in matters pertaining to the worldly kingdom and his own body. We are in the church, which is the kingdom of Christ and of truth, which relies on true faith and pure innocence, is led by them, and is preserved by them. If these things are dear to Luther, he will certainly not know another faith besides the saving one, but he will not involve the Christian simplicity in tricks either. Do you think that the quarrelling shipmaster should be yielded to, if his moroseness can be borne without danger to the ship's banner, lest the whole ship be lost through contention? But meantime, my Bucer, this is in dispute, whether Luther's moroseness and intolerable pride, his biting wit towards the best, his more than rapid vehemence, his desire for the sacrosanct truth and simplicity, by which he fastens and refastens, envelops and perverts whatever he pleases, can this be borne without detriment to the truth, or whether it is proper for the good to navigate in the same ship and to connive at the shipmaster's drunkenness, rashness and impiety, whence afterwards a capital danger is present to all the good. And you say: "Is it not better to bear this than if someone makes such a necessity of the ceremonies of Moses that he does not think that Christ is enough without their observance?" But what, my Bucer, if I neither bear this nor that, for this entirely evacuates Christ, but that resists the recognized truth, and not only resists, but with singular impudence dares to ask that the whole world swear in his words and no other be used than those which he himself is accustomed to use? "But Paul bore that error," you say, "and not only bore it, but also proved himself an observer of ceremonies by his deed." But here you seem to me, Bucer, to see what Paul bore, why he bore it, and how long he bore it. For I find quite different things in Acts 15 [1-21], and especially in Galatians 2 [11-21], where he openly resists Peter's Judaizing and after a few words adds these words: "If I build up what I destroyed, I make myself a transgressor" [Gal 2:18], and again: "Behold, I, Paul, say unto you, that if you be circumcised, Christ will profit you nothing" etc. [Gal 5:2]. Behold, what could have been said more clearly? What more vividly than what he wrote to the Hebrews? What then shall we say? Shall we say what heretics, if Tertullian speaks truly, have said that the apostles have taught something different to each other? But this opinion has long since been expelled from the theatre of Christ as most false.

seg.output: You, who move no stone, again assert: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. And those who doubt that they are of Christ have never preached the gospel with any fruit." But you always omit, my dear Bucere, whose fault it is that we are not one. Certainly not ours. For on our part stands firm truth and Christian simplicity, which cannot be forsaken by us with a safe and sound conscience. Thus, the fault is Luther's that we do not agree. For he, attacked by λογομαχίᾳ καὶ κενοδοξίᾳ, does not give in to truth nor does he cease to throw new debating threads into the middle. Therefore, it is him, not us, that it is true to what you say, that the gospel cannot be preached with any fruit by the dissenters. And so you seem to be right in the law and advice you give to put Luther above all the doctors in the world. For if one looks at the study of cursing and talking, he will take the first place among the doctors and Thersites will take the first place among the Greek heroes. But if one looks at the restoration of piety, learned piety, keen judgement in the sacred, tireless labor and most tried prudence, Luther will not be able to give even a morsel to Capnion, Erasmus, Pellican, Oecolampadius, or Zuinglio, the primary men of true religion.

But you, who move no stone, again bring up the point: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. But those who are in doubt of being Christ's never preach the gospel with any good fruit." For if one looks to the study of reviling and loquacity, then Luther will hold the highest place among the doctors and Thersites will obtain the first place among the Greek heroes. For if, to speak frankly with you, one should look at the love of reviling and loquaciousness, he would hold the foremost place among the doctors and Thersites would obtain the princely place among the Greek heroes. You, however, who move no stone, re-assert: "Those who are not one are not of Christ. But those who are doubted to be of Christ, have never proclaimed the gospel with any profitable fruit." But you, my dear Bucer, always omit whose fault it is that we are not one. It is certainly not ours; for from our side stands firm truth and Christian simplicity, which cannot be deserted by us with a safe and sound conscience. Therefore, it is Luther's fault that we do not agree. He, having been seized by logomachy and vain glory, neither yields to truth nor stops putting forth new contention-nets in the middle. Then, it is suitable to him and not to us, what you say, that the gospel can be preached with no profitable fruit from the dissenters. And thus you seem to show, with what justice and advice you exalt Luther above all the doctors in the world. For if one consider the study of reviling and talking, he will hold the first rank among the doctors, and Thersites would have the principal place among the Greek heroes. But if one contemplates with a pure mind the restoration of piety, learned piety, a piercing judgment in holy matters, indefatigable labour and most exercised prudence, Luther can neither offer a morsel to Capnio, Erasmus, Pellicanus, Oecolampadius, nor Zwingli, the foremost men in true religion. Why then do we linger over these? Why do we still look to persons? To whom Paul's sentence was already long ago most obvious: "From those who seemed to be something—whatever they were, it makes no difference to me—God accepts no man's person" [Gal 2:6], and again: "What then is Apollos, or what is Paul? but ministers by whom you believed, and to each one as the Lord gave" [1 Cor 3:4f.7]. As for the increase and assent of the Lutheran churches, we know that the day of the Lord will declare what sort of works are of each one; and in the meantime we know that the doctrines of Arius and Mahomet have been dispersed almost through the whole East, though we do not yet wholly compare Luther with these. We speak of the increase and assent of the churches.
You ask here, how then shall we repel this evil from us? Certainly without any loss of truth; for it is better to bear this evil of ours even with evil longer than to receive an ill-woven peace with a man who prefers that all glory should be attributed to himself, rather than to the truth. "Shall you then repay railing for railing?" I do not think so. For we are not used to do it hitherto. For how often soever our adversaries have shot forth such thunderbolts against us, which we could not pass over without violating the glory of God and the ministry of the word, yet they have been extinguished with such modesty, that we have not treated any of them as they deserved.

seg.output: What further is there to say? We have not learned, dear Bucer, that we should sit on two chairs. If the body of Christ is bodily at the right hand of God, then it is certainly not bodily at the Last Supper. We are also aware of what the ancients say and how they said it. Moreover, if it is bodily at the right hand of the Father and at the Last Supper at the same time and in one instance, then the body of Christ is infinite. But what is infinite cannot be a body. Hence, the body of Christ is not a body. Indeed, Elijah cried out: “How long will you waver between two opinions?” [1 Kön 18,21]. Paul also exclaims: “What fellowship has light with darkness?” [2 Cor 6,14]. And the entire ancient world shouted: “ἁπλᾶ καῖ σαφῆ τὰ δίκαια,” that is “right and clear justice”. We now testify to God, that we do not begrudge Luther his glory, which God has bestowed upon him, nor do we wish to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do out of love for the truth and simplicity. We will prove this to be the case and now promise you that we will accept Luther as a brother, as soon as he has devoted all his glory to the truth, and has ceased to bite, persecute and harass holy and well-deserving men of the church of Christ, men who actually follow our (or rather God’s) teaching on the Eucharist, whether they be Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or someone else, and has ceased to obscure simplicity, to pervert the right, to articulate the pure in a captious manner, to write barbed documents and infamous (so called) libels, to slander, to libel and to proclaim heretics or self-proclaimed prophets.

seg.output: What is it to many? We have not learned, dear Bucer, to sit on two chairs. If the body of Christ is physically to the right of God, surely it is not physically present at the supper. Nevertheless, we are not unaware of what and how the ancients have spoken. Further, if the body of Christ is present both in the right hand of the Father and at the supper at the same time, then the body of Christ is infinite. But what is infinite is not a body. Therefore, the body of Christ is not a body. Elijah cried out: "How long will you go limping between two opinions?" [1 Kings 18:21] Paul also cried out: "What partnership has light with darkness?" [2 Corinthians 6:14] And the whole antiquity cried out: "Straight and clear are the judgments." We now testify to God that we do not envy the glory given to Luther by God, nor do we wish to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do it out of love for the truth and simplicity. We will prove this to be the case and now we promise you that, as soon as Luther has given all glory to the truth, we will receive him as the closest brother, and the holy and excellent men who have earned the highest esteem in the church of Christ, even those who follow our, or rather God's doctrine on the Eucharist, the innocent, whether it be Carolostadius, or Zwingli, or Oecolampadius, or someone else, will cease to bite and persecute, to obscure simplicity, to pervert the straight, to carry away the pure in a deceptive manner, to write tooth-edged papers and famous, as they say, leaflets, to curse, to calumniate, and to proclaim heretics or self-made prophets. These things will not be difficult for him, nay, he will do them most willingly and of his own accord, if he agrees with our opinion. If not, we would rather hear the evil from an unruly group of Lutherans than to be called hypocrites in reality and in name by all the saints.

Nam semel constituimus, quod et per gratiam dei praestabimus, veritati sanctę et pie simplicitati impendere vitam, nemini cedere, nisi melius aliquid «assidenti fuerit revelatum» [1 Kor 14,30]. Quod autem infinitum est, corpus non est. Ergo Christi corpus corpus non est. Sane Helias clamabat: «Usque quo claudicabitis in utramque partem?» [1 Kön 18,21] Clamat et Paulus: «Quae communia luci cum tenebris?» [2 Kor 6,14] Clamavit et universa vetustas: « ἁπλᾶ καῖ σαφῆ τὰ δίκαια ». Iam vero deum testamur, quod glorię Lutheri , quantum illi impartitus est deus, prorsus non invidemus neque volentes cum eo disceptamus, sed quęcunque facimus, amore veritatis et simplicitatis facimus. Id vero sic habere hac re probabimus ac nunc tibi pollicemur, quod Lutherum ut fratrem arctissimum suscipiemus, quamprimum ille omnem gloriam veritati dederit, sanctos et optime de ecclesia Christi meritos viros, ipsos denique nostrum, imo non nostrum, sed dei de eucharistia dogma sequentes homines innoxios, Carolostadius is sit sive Zuinglius sive Oecolampadius sive alius aliquis, mordere et persequi desierit, simplicitatem nebulis involvere, recta pervertere, pura captiose efferre, dentatas chartas et famosos, ut aiunt, libellos scribere, maledicere, calumniari et hęreticos vel suermerios vates proclamare cessaverit. Haec porro gravia illi non erunt, imo promptissime et sua sponte, si modo nostrę nobiscum, ut ais, fuerit sententię, praestabit. Sin secus, iam malumus a turbulento Lutheranorum male audire manipulo quam ab omnibus sanctis hypocritę ipsa re et nomine appellari. Nam semel constituimus, quod et per gratiam dei praestabimus, veritati sanctę et pie simplicitati impendere vitam, nemini cedere, nisi melius aliquid «assidenti fuerit revelatum» [1 Kor 14,30]. «Breve est tempus vitę, quod restat» [1 Kor 7,29], inconstans mundus, inconstantiores homines, pavidi et ad sanctam dei crucem trepidi.
seg.output: What then to many? We have not learned, dearest Bucere, to sit on two chairs. If Christ's body is physically to the right of God, certainly it is not physically at the table. Nor, in the meantime, do we ignore what and how the ancients have spoken. Further, if it is physically both to the right of the Father and at the table simultaneously and at the same time, Christ's body is infinite. But what is infinite is not a body. Therefore, Christ's body is not a body. Certainly Elijah cried out: "How long will you go limping between two opinions?" [1 Kings 18:21] Paul also cries out: "What communion has light with darkness?" [2 Corinthians 6:14] And the whole antiquity cried out: "Straight and clear are the just." Now, however, we testify to God that we do not envy Luther's glory, whatever God has imparted to him, nor do we wish to dispute with him, but whatever we do, we do out of love for truth and simplicity. We will prove this to be so in this matter and now we promise you that we will receive Luther as the closest brother as soon as he has given all glory to the truth, holy and most deserving men of the Church of Christ, even those following the dogma of the Eucharist, innocent, whether it be Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or anyone else, cease to bite and persecute, wrap simplicity in clouds, pervert straight paths, carry away pure things craftily, write jagged papers and famous, as they say, pamphlets, rail, calumniate, and proclaim heretics or false prophets. These things will not be difficult for him, nay, he will do them readily and of his own accord, provided that he agrees with our opinion. If not, we would rather hear evil from the turbulent troop of Lutherans than be called hypocrites by all the saints, in fact and in name. For we have once established, and will do by the grace of God, that we will devote our lives to holy truth and pious simplicity, yielding to no one, unless something better has been revealed to him who sits [1 Corinthians 14:30]. "The time that remains is short" [1 Corinthians 7:29], the fickle world, even more fickle men, timid and fearful of the holy cross of God.

What then is our opinion about many things? We have not learned, my dear Bucer, that two chairs sit together. If the body of Christ is physically to the right of God, certainly it is not physically in the supper. At the same time, we do not ignore what and how the ancients spoke. We will now prove this to be true and we now promise you that we will receive Luther as our closest brother as soon as he has devoted all glory to the truth, and he has stopped biting and persecuting the holy and most deserving men of the church of Christ, even those who follow our doctrine (or rather not ours, but God's) of the Eucharist, the innocent, whether it be Carolostadius or Zwingli or Oecolampadius or someone else. These things will not be difficult for him, but he will do them willingly and of his own accord, if he is of the same opinion with us, as you say. If not, we would rather be heard by the turbulent Lutheran rabble than be called hypocrites in deed and in name by all the saints. For we have once decided and, by the grace of God, we will carry out, to devote our lives to the sacred truth and pious simplicity, yielding to no one, unless something better has been revealed to him who sits by [1 Cor 14,30]. "For the time that remains is short" [1 Cor 7,29], the unstable world, more unstable men, timid and fearful of the holy cross of God. But we do not want to be marked by this Pauline sentence: "Everyone who wants to please in the flesh must compel you to be circumcised, only that they should not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" etc. [Gal 6,12].
Now, what you have not only allowed but were even the authors of subscribing to the Saxon Confession, we neither approve nor disapprove, since, as the proverb says, what is done cannot be undone. We would never do such a thing without consulting you. But perhaps it is so ordained by God that we are once deprived of all human aid and fellowship. But, "Let the will of the Lord be done" [Acts 21,14]. This is clearer than can be denied, that in that confession there are some things contrary to sincere doctrine, which we have formerly attacked and disapproved of, some things too obscure and childish.

But those things which they speculate about confession, absolution, and mass, are more widely known than needs to be repeated, and very well known is that which they defined about the Eucharist. And this is what our own completely condemned. For whom did they condemn, if not us? Or how could it be that after so many excellent works they still had not properly understood ours? Zwingli had written a great deal, Oecolampadius had written much that was religious, and so had Bucer, and at Marburg the confession of both sides was heard. Yet the audacious condemnation followed.

Et nihilominus impudens secuta est damnatio . Neque vero aliud tum, aliud nunc dicebant nostri. Eadem semper fuit doctrina. Iam vero, quod rebus publicis vestris non modo permisistis, verum etiam authores fuistis subscribendi Confessioni Saxonicae , nec probare nec improbare volumus, quum factum, ut fertur proverbio, infectum esse nequit . Sane nos tale quippiam inconsultis vobis minime fecissemus. Verum ita fortassis a deo statutum, ut semel omni destituamur humano auxilio et sodalitio. Sed age, «fiat voluntas domini» [Apg 21,14]. Id vero manifestius est, quam negari possit, in ea confessione esse, quę syncerę doctrinę adversa sunt, quędam item, quę a nobis ipsis olim impugnata et improbata sunt, quędam etiam satis obscura et puerilia. Cuiusmodi illud est, quod per sacramenta velut instrumenta donetur spiritus sanctus, quod iisdem confirmetur fides , quod baptismus necessarius sit ad salutem . Loquuntur autem de baptismo aquae. Ea vero, quae de confessione, absolutione et missa philosophantur , notiora sunt, quam repetere necessarium sit, notissimum et illud, quod de eucharistia definierunt. Quae et nostra prorsus damnarunt . Nam quos damnaverunt alios, si nos non damnarunt? Aut quomodo fieri posset, ut nostra post tot egregia opuscula nondum rite intellexissent? Scripserat perplurima Zuinglius , scripserat multa et religiosa Oecolampad[ius] , scripserat et Bucerus , conveneratis Marpurgi , utriusque partis audita est confessio . Et nihilominus impudens secuta est damnatio . Neque vero aliud tum, aliud nunc dicebant nostri. Eadem semper fuit doctrina. Quid, quod ipse Zuinglius tam dilucide, tam etiam religiose de sacramentis, imo de tota religione et «Ad Carolum » et «Ad principes Augustae congregatos» scripsit, ut nemo unquam clarius de hac re scripserit?
seg.output: We neither approve nor disapprove of your having not only allowed, but even been the authors of subscribing to the Saxon Confession, since, as the proverb goes, an accomplished deed cannot be undone. Certainly we would not have done such a thing without consulting you. But perhaps it was so ordained by God, that once we should be deprived of all human aid and fellowship. But, "Let the will of the Lord be done" [Acts 21:14]. And it is more manifest than can be denied, that there are in that confession some things contrary to sincere doctrine, some which we have formerly opposed and disapproved, and some which are quite dark and childish. Such is that which affirms, that the Holy Ghost is bestowed by the Sacraments as instruments, that faith is confirmed by them, and that baptism is necessary to salvation. And they speak of baptism by water. But those things which they discourse of in confession, absolution, and mass, are more known than to need to be repeated; and that which they have determined of the Eucharist is most notorious. Which things we have altogether condemned. For whom have they condemned, if they have not condemned us? Or how could it be, that after so many excellent works, they did not yet understand our doctrine aright? Zuinglius had written many things; Oecolampadius had written much, and that devoutly; Bucer had written also; the Confession of both parties had been heard at Marpurg; and yet an impudent sentence of condemnation followed. Neither then, nor now, did our men say any thing else. The same doctrine was still maintained. But what if Zuinglius himself hath written so clearly, and with such piety of the Sacraments, yea, of the whole religion, both in his "Letter to Charles" and his "Address to the Princes assembled at Augsburg", that no man ever wrote more clearly upon this subject?
